---
title: Color (continuous)
---

Continuous color palettes are used to map numeric values to colors. They are specified in the `TO` clause of a `SCALE` statement when scaling fill or stroke:

```ggsql
SCALE fill TO viridis
```

ggsql includes a wide selection of perceptually uniform and scientifically designed color palettes from several sources. The default palette for continuous color scales is `navia` from the Scientific Color Maps project.

You can easily use your own palette by providing an array of colors. ggsql will interpolate between the colors in the array to automatically, so at it's simplest, a manual continuous palette can be defined as an array of two colors, e.g.

```ggsql
SCALE fill TO ['cream', 'firebrick']
```

or, using hex color notation

```ggsql
SCALE fill TO ['#fffdd0', '#b22222']
```

However, not all palettes are equally good since we should take care that they are perceptually uniform and color blind friendly. Due to this it is advised to use one of the included palettes if at all possible since they have been designed with this in mind.

## Crameri Scientific Colour Maps

A comprehensive set of scientifically derived color maps designed to be perceptually uniform, colorblind-friendly, and avoid perceptual artifacts that can misrepresent data.

::: {.callout-note}
**Source:** Crameri, F. (2018). Scientific colour maps. Zenodo. [doi:10.5281/zenodo.1243862](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.1243862)

**Reference:** Crameri, F., Shephard, G.E., & Heron, P.J. (2020). The misuse of colour in science communication. *Nature Communications*, 11, 5444.
:::

## ColorBrewer Sequential

Sequential palettes from ColorBrewer, designed for mapping ordered data from low to high. These use 9 colors that are interpolated for continuous scales.

::: {.callout-note}
**Source:** Brewer, C.A. (2002). ColorBrewer: Color Advice for Cartography. [colorbrewer2.org](https://colorbrewer2.org)
:::

## Matplotlib Perceptually Uniform

These palettes were developed for matplotlib and are designed to be perceptually uniform, meaning equal steps in data produce equal perceptual changes in color. They are also designed to work well for colorblind viewers and when printed in grayscale.

::: {.callout-note}
**Source:** van der Walt, S. & Smith, N. (2015). A Better Default Colormap for Matplotlib. SciPy 2015.
:::

| Name | Gradient | Description |
|------|----------|-------------|
| `viridis` | ![](gradient_viridis.svg){height=20} | Dark purple through blue and green to yellow |
| `plasma` | ![](gradient_plasma.svg){height=20} | Dark purple through pink to yellow (higher contrast) |
| `magma` | ![](gradient_magma.svg){height=20} | Black through purple and pink to light yellow |
| `inferno` | ![](gradient_inferno.svg){height=20} | Black through red and orange to light yellow |
| `cividis` | ![](gradient_cividis.svg){height=20} | Dark blue through gray to yellow (colorblind-optimized) |

## Choosing a Palette

### For general continuous data

- **`navia`** (default) - Good all-purpose choice, perceptually uniform
- **`viridis`** - Excellent for print, colorblind-safe, perceptually uniform
- **`batlow`** - Wide perceptual range, good for scientific data

### For data with a meaningful midpoint

Use a diverging palette:

- **`vik`** or **`berlin`** - Clear red/blue contrast
- **`roma`** - Warm/cool contrast without red/blue

### For data representing categories with magnitude

Consider multi-sequential palettes:

- **`oleron`** - Good for topographic data

### For periodic/cyclic data

Use a cyclic palette:

- **`romao`** - Smooth transitions that wrap around

### Colorblind considerations

All Crameri and matplotlib palettes are designed with colorblind accessibility in mind. For maximum accessibility:

- **`cividis`** - Specifically optimized for all forms of color vision deficiency
- **`viridis`**, **`plasma`**, **`magma`**, **`inferno`** - All colorblind-safe
